docs.title: Comms / UX / UI Design Redesign Project - Week 1
Project Overview
docs.text: This project focuses on analyzing and redesigning an existing website using established UX and UX design principles while also documenting the full design process. The primary goal is to improve usability, accessiblity, visual hierarchy, and the overall user experience. This project aims to really clarify the core purpose of the selected website.

docs.title: Website Options
docs.text: Our team discussed multiple websties for redesign, including Craigslist, 4chan, and Magic Stronghold. After evaluating the pros and cons of each option, the group ultimately selected Magic Stronghold as the most suitable, for a meaningful redesign project.

docs.title: Chosen Website: Magic Stronghold
docs.text: Magic Stronghold was selected because the current website shows several usability and design problems that go against core principles of UX and UI design. The interface appears visually outdated, navigation structure is not clear. In addition, the visual hierarchy is all over the place, key UX and UI design principles are not applied.

docs.title: Redesign Goals
docs.text: The redeisgn will focus on simplifying navigation, improving layout consistency, enhancing overall readability, and visual hierarchy. Our team will also apply recognized UX heuristics and modern visual design practices to create a more intuitive and complete user experience.

docs.title: Target Audience
docs.text: Magic Stronghold serves a targeted audience, this audience is interested in fantasy and gaming, including trading card games, board games, model kits, and card tournaments. The redesign will consider both new visitors and returning members.

docs.title: UX / UI Principles Applied
docs.text: The redesign process will use what we have learned so far in the program, including usability principles, consistency and standards, user control and freedom, aesthetic and minimalist design and accessibility.

docs.title: Comms / UX / UI Design Redesign Project - Week 2
docs.text: This week was to explore the stages of UX methodology and discuss key usability factors that can influence design decisions.

docs.title: Five stages of UX Methodlogy
docs.text:
UX methodology provides an understanding to the user and helps develop effective design strategies. Having a clear process helps developers create a more user-focused application.

The first stage is Emphathize, where we seek to understand users by identifying their needs, frustration, and goals. This is done through creating user stories, observations, and problem statements.

The next stage is Define, where we analyze the core problems we have discovered. This is done by having a problem statement focusing on the issues and solving it.

The next stage is Ideate, this stage focuses on brainstorming and creating as many possible solutions as possible. The goal here is to be creative and explore all possible approaches.

The next stage is Prototype, this is where we take the most promising solutions and we test them. This gives an idea to the team on how a solution might function in a live environment.

The last stage is Test, which involves releasing the prototype to users and getting feedback.

docs.title: 7 Usability Factors
docs.text:
The seven usability factors provides a checklist for evaluating how well a product or service meets a users needs. Together, this ensures that the design is practical and visually appealing.

  • Useful — Is the product or service useful?
  • Usable — Is the product or service easy to use?
  • Findable — Can users easily locate what they need?
  • Credible — Does the product inspire trust?
  • Desirable — Is the product visually and emotionally appealing?
  • Accessible — Can people of varying abilities use it?
  • Valuable — Does it deliver value to users and the business?

docs.title: In-Class Real-World UX/UI Example: Ketchup Bottle Redesign
docs.text:
A strong example we disussed in class the the UX design of a traditional glass ketchup bottle. The older glass bottles were poorly designed because users often had difficulties getting the ketchup out of the bottle cleanly. This created a frustrating experience.

Over time, designers redesigned the product into a plastic squeeze bottle that also had the cap at the bottom. This redesign improved user experience greatly by allowing better control.

This example demonstrated to us how UX design can make a simple everyday product many times better.

docs.title: Applying the UX Methodology
docs.text:
After analyzing the ketchup bottle, the design process can be linked to the UX methodology:

Empathize — Users experienced frustration with glass bottles.

Define — The product was messy, inconsistent, and required effort.

Ideate — Designers explored new materials and dispensing options.

Prototype — The plastic squeeze bottle design was developed.

Test — Users quickly confirmed the new design was faster, cleaner, easier, and just better.

docs.title: Usability Factors
docs.text:
Useful — Dispenses ketchup efficiently.

Usable — Requires less effort and strength.

Findable — Opening cap is easy to locate.

Credible — Trusted and reliable function.

Desirable — More modern and convenient.

Accessible — Easier for children and users with limited strength.

Valuable — Reduces waste and improves satisfaction.

docs.title: UX in Everyday Products
docs.text: UX design is not just limited to websites and applications, it also works for everyday products like ketchup bottles and remote controls. Well designed products feel intuitive and require little effort from users. In contrast, poorly designed products often cause frustration.

docs.title: The Relationship Between UX/UI and Business Success
docs.text:
Effective UX/UI design has a direct impact on business performance. Products are designed well and easy to use have higher user satisfaction, which lead to higher user retention.

While poor UX/UI design can decrease revenue, lower user retention, and negative branding.

docs.title: Comms / UX / UI Design Redesign Project - Week 3
docs.text: This week we focused on applying user-centered design principles to the website redesign. The main purpose of this class was to design based on real user needs rather than relying on personal preferences or assumptions. The class also reinforced the ideas of strong UX principles, which reflect how a business can grow.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
• Personas
  • User Scenarios
  • User Stories
  • UX Artifacts

docs.title: What we did
docs.text:
During class, the team created multiple personas to represent different types of users who might visit the website. Each persona included unique characteristics, behaviors, needs, goals, income, and pain points. Developing these personas helped provide a clear idea on who we should redesign the website for.

Using the personas, we then developed specific user stories for each, to better understand how different users might interact with the website. This process let us get a rough idea how real users could interact with the website and where we could redesign certain parts.

docs.title: Comms / UX / UI Design Redesign Project - Week 4
docs.text: This week focused on creating clear problem statements to guide the redesign process. We learned that creating effective problem statements requires us to understand the ideal users and clearly define the problem and the purpose of the redesign. We learned a structure approach called 5 W's which help ensure the problem is well scoped and actionable. We also discussed Information Architecture which focuses on organizing and categorizing items in the menu

docs.title: Problem Statement
docs.text: A strong problem statement should include a concise paragraph describing the issue the redesigned website, product, or service aims to resolve.

docs.title: The 5 W's
docs.text:
• Who — Who is using the site?

  • What — What is the site offering, and what should be the main focus?

  • Where — Where will the experience occur (primarily online)?

  • When — When will users need this solution (immediate vs. future use)?

  • Why — Why is the redesign necessary?

docs.title: Feature List
docs.text: The feature list defines the project scope and outlines what will be implemented in the website redesign. Having scope helps keep the project focused on user needs and business goals.

docs.title: Example Features
docs.text:
• Update branding (colors and typography)
  • Redesign home page layout
  • Improve navigation menu

docs.title: Ideation
docs.text: This phase focuses on creating as many potential solutions as possible in a safe non-judgmental environment. A class activity we did to accomplish this was Crazy 8's. We were tasked with rapid fire wireframe sketching, where we only had 30 seconds to sketch certain interfaces. The goal was to encourage creative thinking.

docs.title: Information Architecture
docs.text:
Information architecture (IA) focuses on organizing and labeling content so users can easily find what they need.

IF is comprised of several interconnected systems

  • Navigation design - Determines menu type, hierachy, and structure

    • Hierarchy
      • Deep - Few top-level links with many nested pages
      • Shallow - Mnay top-level links with many nested pages
    • Labeling - Defines the language style used in menus

  • Content inventory - A complete list of site pages and content

  • Sitemap - A visual represetation of site structure
  • Wireframes - Simple layout sketches showing page structure

docs.title: Group Exercise
docs.text:
As a group, we practiced information architecture by categorizing the following items into approprite top-level menu headings:

  • Accessibility
  • Audition Info
  • Contact Us
  • Current Shows
  • Donate
  • Getting Here
  • Join Our Team
  • Musical Theatre Camp
  • Our Story
  • Past Shows
  • Ticket Information
  • Venue Information
  • Visitor Questions (FAQ)
  • Volunteering

This shows us that organizing information architecture is important to let the websites content become structured in a clear, logical, and user friendly way. This also correlates with the business perspective since effective IA can increase user retention, which can increase revenue.
